abstract: After six years of stagnation, pressure is mounting on the chief executive of General Electric to boost shares.
snippet: After six years of stagnation, pressure is mounting on the chief executive of General Electric to boost shares.
lead_paragraph: EVEN by the standards of a company that builds everything from light bulbs to power plants and straddles markets as varied as prime-time TV and commercial finance, General Electric’s mammoth project along the Hudson River north of Albany is staggering. The company plans to lay down more than 28,000 feet of rail and 267,000 square yards of plastic beside the river’s edge — all to haul nearly 400,000 tons of sediment from the bottom of the Hudson beginning in 2009, seven years and $500 million after G.E. agreed to undertake the job.

headline.main: Is G.E. Too Big for Its Own Good?
headline.print_headline: Is G.E. Too Big for Its Own Good?
